title: IKEA Lagra Lamp Replacement Pivot Mount

description.text:
I ended up busting my wife's working light for her sewing and boy was I in trouble for it.
So I designed and printed this part to repair the lamp.
My first thing designed in 123D Design, So far soo good. I didn't get to replicate the "ripples" that the lamp section interlocks tho.
I'll see how it goes post print and redesign if required.. trying to figure out the polylines for it was difficult. I know the lamp is worth next to nothing. But why throw away something we can fix with a 3D Printer! The first print Bridged incredibly well. However as the hole in the nipple goes "all the way through" it droops as it has nothing to stick to in the middle. I also made the mounting holes a tad too small and snapped the print. Revised version soon!

(untested)  
I would suggest printing with the circular nipple at the top if you have an actively cooled hotend and are a bridging champion.  
Otherwise print it the same orientation the file comes and use support for the nipple.

comments.text:
thanks
I made the same mistake
comments.author: Normand

comments.text:
Go figure.
I design a usful 3d printer part and its crickets for months.
I design a replacement part for an Ikea lamp.. triple the downloads in 2 days :/
comments.author: atreidae

author: atreidae

title: Pool Leaf skimmer V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Connected to the outlet pipe of your swimming pool uses a venturi effect to suck surface debris through the nozzle and into a bag.
You will need 39mm (1,5in) diameter hose attached to your pool outlet and into the nozzle and a bag to catch the leaves. Something like an orange (fruit) bag. V1 works very well and this is hopefully an improvement.
The float before was also the funnel but as its printed getting it watertight without printing it fairly solid is a pain. This one can use a 600ml plastic cool drink bottle as a float.
The arms connecting the pipe to the float has broken a few times and a bit of super glue works but I've changed them to 4mm shafts dowel sticks from a local hardware should do. If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

comments.text:
After a year, maybe you have a picture or a video, because I'm curious how it connects to return?
Thanks!
comments.author: Dosperado

comments.text: Look at the V1 design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:514828 it uses a flexible pipe from the water return inlet that is directed through the opening into a stocking or similar bag. The water creates a venturi effect that sicks leaves and floating debris into the bag.
comments.author: Redsalamander

comments.text: I don't understand how this works.
comments.author: ScottSEA

comments.text: I've had this in my pool for about a year now. It works great and doesn't seem to be affected by pool chemicals. The threaded rods I used could have faired better as they are corroding but using another material will solve that. Stainless is available as is brass. The stocking type socks I use seem to wear our pretty quick they last about 2 weeks till they start tearing. I use a cable tie to hold the sock on, you can have it not to tight so its loose enough to get the sock of and tight enough to hold it.
comments.author: Redsalamander

remixed_from.title: A Card and Rubber band Wallet

title: remixed card and rubber band wallet

description.text:
This is a remix of the excellent rubber band wallet from FigaflorsiBraves.  
This remix features holes for x-band rubber bands which I used as I found the original rubber bands almost impossible to find. X-bands should be available in your local stationary shop or favourite auction site.   
The corners have also been rounded a little more so it sits better in your pocket.  
and  
This model also features a deeper and more rounded cut-out for card extraction - eye holes have also been added for increased nonsensicality.
Printed with honeycomb infill at 30% density with no solid layers.

title: MK8 Printhead horizontal Carriage and Ninja Flex / TPU Filament path Adapter

description.text:
This is a new Horizontal carriage design for my RepRap Mendel to hold the new MK8 all metal head.  Also included is a  Filament path adapter that provides the capability to print with Ninja Flex by eliminating any path for the Ninja Flex to squeeze out after the pinch rollers.  The Filament path adapter design is specifically for a MK8 head that uses a grooved bearing and brass drive gear.  With the fan, the all metal MK8 head allows you to print at temperatures as high as 280deg C.  Time to print materials like Taulman Nylon.  Another benefit is you gain an additional inch in print height over the traditional Wade extruder; make sure you update your firmware Z limits.  
You will need longer M3 screws to make this work.  I reused many parts of the provided hardware on different sides and got creative with others.  Make sure you have a plan before ripping apart your only extruder.
8-12-2017 - Been playing around with changing my MK8 Print head into a MK10 All Metal (micro Swiss) print head and now I am ready to share it.  You need a drill index and calibers like the ones they sell at Harbor Freight so you can measure the Micro Swiss cold end extruder tube.  Also a #4-40 tap or similar and set screw  A good steady drill press and anchored vise is required so things don't get crazy as accurate new hole(s) are required to allow proper heat transfer.  In your current MK8 threaded barrel receiver drill out the threads and hole stepping up 1 drill size at a time until it is the perfect size to receive the cold end of the All Metal MK10 print head.  You'll also need a tapped hole in the face of the Barrel receiver to secure the cold end.  If you bought the real Swiss made print head then it came with high quality thermal compound to goop on the cold end and slide into your newly drilled and tapped extruder receiver.  Use the MK10 flex adapter to set the height the cold end extends above the inside face of the receiver.  (The MK10 flex adapter may need an SLA printer for best results [see my 3DHubs page]). Assemble and enjoy. Use some of the thermal compound on the fan heatsink. (You may need a new MK10 Hot Block if you didn't buy one with the all metal hot end.  The only other change is the height above the print bed to the carriage is greatly reduced so a new MK10 print cooler is included which is shorter.
2-7-2017 - A comment of Extruder Types: MK8 vs MK10, If you have the choice and are using a single printhead (as this design implies) a MK8 printhead beats a MK10 print head hands down for versatility in Material / Temp ranges.  Why?  The MK10 is designed specifically for multiple printheads being used simultaneously because it purposely reduces the "hot zone" to reduce oozing of the head not being used; and there in lies the problem.  This compromise requires higher overall temps (+10deg C over normal MK8 print temps) being needed to kept the very tip of the extruder hot enough to melt the plastic and therefore materials like PETg will cause damage to the internal teflon tub (Printing @ 255C to get acceptable results; or really slow for lower temps.). On my MK8 printers I print PETg @ 240-245 and 45mm/sec with beautiful results and no teflon tube changes for years.  My MK10 printer, All Metal upgrade and now they print as nice. Hmmm.  Just a thought.  So for those that landed here for a reason, the MK8 printhead is a great design, keep it and keep on printing.
9-19-2015 - Printed the filament cooler for myself and bought some PLA to play.  Simple as, it works perfect.  Turn on at 100% fan speed after the first layer (some fans may require lower).  No sagging of the filament when bridging, no warping of overhangs.  Extruder only dips a few degrees before recovering when it initially turns on with no effect to the filament extruding.  No effect on bed temperature when it comes on.  Will be using it on my ABS prints during bridging and overhangs only at 50% speed.  (Tested, makes great on ABS bridging @ 50%.  Test print objects come out sharp!)
9-18-2015 - Replaced the cooling fan part with a version that raises it an additional 1mm to account for it being so close to the bed in the previous design.  This insures clearance between the printing part and the cooling housing.  
9-13-2015 - Added two parts to the stl files.  One is an extended carriage if you need to replace the stock GeeTech (61oz) stepper with a stronger but slightly longer Nema 17 stepper (81oz).  The other part is a filament cooler for when you print with PLA.  Normally printers come with fans that blow air across the print to cool it faster and help the plastic to solidify.  This is helpful when bridging and printing small parts.  This fan can normally be controlled automatically in the slicer when connected into your controller properly.  The design is for a 40mm external dimension fan (32mm hole spacing) (20mm high).  It is not printed as part of the carriage, but instead is glued on afterwards as shown in the 3D rendering.  The fan is designed to be held with 3mm screws (printed mounting holes are 20mm deep)  It has a duct precisely angled to get the flow of air on the part and limit the air flow across the print head to prevent the print head from cooling (or that is the plan)  Support should not be needed to print; good bridging settings will be.  Print as oriented in the stock file.  
12-30-2014 - After playing around with the MK8 head I purchased and supplementing with other parts from RP_One like their excellent teflon lined extruder feed tube (1.75mm Filament).  I finally have a complete MK8 print head that provides better results than my old J-Head extruder (and they where pretty good).  The head has been fully tested and and works amazing with little to absolutely no ooze.  The NinjaFlex adapter also works flawless and produced awesome results on some rubber feet I needed to print.  It's working rock solid.  Let me know if you have any questions.

title: QI backpack for Xiaomi Power Bank

description.text: Backpack for the Mi Power Bank 10400 (Xiaomi Powerbank). Since I am often on the go and need a wireless charger both my watch and other QI compatible devices, I created a small little back for the Power Bank which fits a standard "hockeypuck" eBay QI charger.

Printed with ColorFabb Dutch Orange 1.75 PLA. First layer on 205c and the rest on 200c. 20% infill @ 200 micron.  
I used two strips of double sided tape to attach the print on the Power Bank. Used it for a couple of weeks without any problems of getting loose from the charger.

I saw the featured pixel tree topper (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194864) and got inspired to make a Mario themed Christmas tree with it. Credit for the star of course goes to knape. The coin is a modified version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209089) that was created by HooliganLabs. The box and cloud ornaments were designed by my good friend Kyle Langley at my request, feel free to reuse and modify those as needed. The ornaments were printed fairly small in order to fit them onto a two foot tree as a IT office decoration. But there shouldn't be any issues scaling them higher/lower for your needs that I am aware of.

I printed all objects at 3mm layer height and 10% infill. I'd probably do a higher infill on the star if I did it again, or if you have the option to do thicker walls, as some warped while printing and didn't quite come out perfect. I printed it all in ABS, presumably this will all be fine in PLA as well.

author: allenZ

description.text:
After losing the original mounts for my Ikea 16986 blinds, I designed these as replacements. I am using these blinds as a projector screen mounted to the ceiling. This is the revision I have been using for over a year without failure (read instructions!) Installation You may notice that the mounting holes are on the same side as the post. This means you will need to install this side first, as the blinds will prevent you from getting your screwdriver in. Thus,
  • Chose a location and mark holes for where you want to mount the brackets.
  • Install the bracket with the post first (End 1.stl)
  • Mount the blinds onto the post, and while someone holds them for you, mount the remaining bracket (End 2.stl)

• Rotate X axis 90 degrees (or so they print flat).

  • For strength, use 100% infill.

    • There is a lot of force applied to the post, but after 1 year of use mine is still holding strong.
  • Use whatever layer height you want!
    • It is a replacement part, aesthetics don't matter. I used 0.4mm.

This is a customizable carriage for linear guide applications. The guide itself is any rectangular profile but I designed the carriage with masson screed profile in mind.
Adjustment screws allow to tighten the wheels support against the profile. To have the carriage parallel to the profile, the screws are installed on one side while the opposite is left on its stops.
Washers are used to keep the wheels in the middle of their axle. Video available on YouTube

• Adjust the variables for your purpose
  • Set the view to flat_packed to get each individual pieces to cut

All dimensions are in millimeters.
  • View - View the carriage fully or partially assembled or view individual parts
  • Show_Profile - Show the profile (the screed) in assembled views
  • Part - Choose which individual parts to render
  • In_2D - Enable 2D projection / laser cutting path
  • Material_Thickness - Thickness of used the material.
  • Material_Clearance - Thinnest part of the material, thinner may break easily.
  • Carriage_Length - This value allows to extend the overall carriage length.
  • Carriage_Wheel_Box_Length - This value allows to extend the length of the wheel support.
  • Carriage_Wheel_Number - Number of wheels along rail axis. In most case, it's 2.
  • Screed_Section_D1, Screed_Section_D2, Screed_Thickness - Profile dimension (Screed_Thickness is only used for display purpose).
  • Bearing_Inner_Diameter, Bearing_Outer_Diameter, Bearing_Width, Axle_Diameter, Axle_Nut_Inscribed_Diameter, Axle_Nut_Thickness, Axle_Washer_Thickness, Axle_Washer_Outer_Diameter - Wheel hardware.
  • Adjustment_Screw_Diameter, Adjustment_Screw_Nut_Inscribed_Diameter, Adjustment_Screw_Nut_Thickness - Adjustment screws hardware.
  • Side_Screw_Diameter, Side_Screw_Nut_Inscribed_Diameter, Side_Screw_Nut_Thickness - Side mount hardware.
  • Small_Clearance, Large_Clearance - Clearance used in many parts of the design.

My Sci-Fi inspired Rocket ship desk tidy. The internal cavity is large enough to hold a selection of pens and pencils inside a retro style 1950's rocket ship. I would recommend painting in metallic acrylic paints for best results.  
Main body and legs are  just two parts for easy printing and minimal assembly. Stands 35cm tall when assembled. 80mm diameter x 150 cm tall cavity. Can be printed on Makerbot Replicator G5 or scaled 80% for Replicator Mini.  
Please do send me any pictures should you print and paint your own.

Simply print out the 3 parts and glue the top handle (probe) into position.  
I recommend preparing finished surface by rubbing with medium and fine grade sand paper before painting with acrylic paints available from your local art suppliers.

title: Circus Air Calliope Wagon c.1920 Kit

description.text: This model of the Ringling Bros. Air Calliope wagon No. 2 was made from a plan in the July-August 1997 â€œLittle Circus Wagonâ€, the official publication of Circus Model Builders International.  It is in kit form to facilitate printing and preserving maximum detail.  A .jpg of the graphics can also be down loaded to paste on the wagon to complete the detail.  The high relief scrolls on the sky boards were created using â€œPhotoToMeshâ€ from Ransen Software as were the curved window in the sides of the wagon.  Modeling was done in Autodesk 123D Beta and modified in Autodesk Meshmixer. The .sla files are sized for a scale of 1/4-inch = 1 foot.  I have also printed it at 2x scale, and that is the model in the picture.  At half scale (~HO) wheels, brake wheel, and flag posts will probably not print acceptably.

You will need to print two copies of Sides and Front and Rear Wheels, four copies of the flag posts (if you choose to use the parade flags) and one copy of all other parts.
I paint my models mostly before assembly using acrylics.
I use an acetone/ABS slurry as my primary glue, but it is less effective over painted parts where Super Glue comes into play. The graphics can be printed on decal paper, but I find using white glue to paste on designs printed on plain paper perfectly acceptable. Download some air calliope music to your smart phone play list and you will have a very good circus music box!

author: danbze

description.text:
This spool is made to be able to quickly change plastic of different colors which are on rolls of different diameters. Each hook is easily adjustable with a single bolt in a captive nut. It is important that the spool does not turn too easily which would allow the filament to get tangled.
The arms of the spool are aluminium extrusions of 10x10 mm. The idea for the construction is borrowed from the "damped spool" by FatFreddie.

Cut 3 pieces of about 22 cm of 10x10 aluminium extrusion. Fix the arms with small bolts to the center piece. In my case the center piece fitted so tight, I had to use a heating gun to help and there was no need for bolts. Use 25 mm M3 bolts and nuts in the hooks at the end of the arms.
I designed this using 123d designer; the design files are included if you want to make any changes.

author: dennisj10

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536486 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=536486

Using the following options: first_letter = K
second_letter = S

the spool-holders here on thingiverse so far where all designed around pvc pipes of various imperial sizes - this design addresses that :-)  
build from a standard drainpipe piece with 40mm outer diameter a bit of wood, both cut to length and from the same hardware store :-)  
simple/lean design, quick to print and assemble - and allows super fast filament change (no center hub to unscrew/mount)

needed parts:
  • one pvc-pipe: outer diameter 40mm (inner diameter 36mm)
  • one piece of wood 39mm wide and 4.5mm thick (mine was sold as 40mm x 5mm x 1000mm)
  • four roller-skate bearings (608)

assembly:
  • print both parts times four
  • from the pipe cut two pieces - for example 9cm in length
  • cut two pieces of wood - eg 18cm
  • first push the bearing in the sleave and the holder on the piece of wood
  • then push the bearing assembly onto the holder (the holder might fail otherwise)
  • align each pair of bearing holder on the two wood pieces
  • mount the pipe pieces

Note:
pipe pieces with 9cm length and the wood pieces with 18cm worked for the most common spools i have lying around; these parameters might need to be adjusted to whatever spoolsize you mostly use

Philipp, Bre, Zach and I brought one of their MakerBots to a bar in NYC. While sitting there printing objects and drinking Sangria, I quickly tossed together this model and printed it.
The bartender got impressed enough to give us all a tequila shot on the house, of course drunk from the printed glass! To regenerate/edit the model, our under development and undocumented MetaCADEvaluator plugin is needed. This is part of the development version of CSGEvaluator for Art of Illusion:
objects.reprap.org/wiki/Builders/Metalab/AoI_CSG_Evaluator

comments.text:
Anything that impresses a bar tender enough to get a free shot is essential technology. You should be eligible for that R
&
amp;D tax rebate they keep talking about.

Used for sizing your printer to EMT Conduit.
Each piece contains the "official" size in the middle ring, and provides a -1mm, -0.5mm, +0.5mm and +1mm ring, to allow you to find the right fit. (slip, press fit, etc) EMT 0-5: Used for sizing the OD of a 1/2" conduit (0.706"), and the ID of a 3/4" conduit (0.824") EMT 0-75: Used for sizing the OD of a 3/4" conduit (0.922"), and the ID of a 1" conduit (1.049") EMT 1-0: Used for sizing the OD of a 1" conduit (1.163"), and the ID of a 1-1/4" conduit (1.38") EMT 1-25: Used for sizing the OD of a 1-1/4" conduit (1.51"), and the ID of a 1-1/2" conduit (1.61")

If the EMT conduit fits in/over the middle ring, your 3D printer has excellent resolution! (Use the official size when designing parts) If however, your printer is like mine, and needs a "fudge factor" to fit correctly, then you can figure out that correction factor by finding which step it fits on. Sample: Need to find my printer's correction factor for slip fitting over a 1/2 EMT pipe:
  • Print EMT 0-5;
  • In my case, the EMT goes in to the second largest ring.
  • My correction factor is +0.5mm to slip my prints over 1/2 EMT
    • Created in Alibre - Source files included

description.text: This is what I pictured in my head as soon as I saw the above thing. I made the box a tube and added some threads to the top and bottom. I also included a top cap and bottom cap. But what makes this AWESOME is the inner section of the threaded tube that will allow you to make this carrier of sorts as long as you want! Print some http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1272 to add a male buckle for this Have fun and try coming up with different modules to add for a truly modular thing! NOTE: This has been printed by Thaed and it seems to fit perfectly together! So it should be good to go!! UPDATES Files have been updated to ones generated in Inventor. They are much cleaner now and look purddy... :-D I have also included the Inventor files. Thanks goes to ub3rgeek for his bolt thing he made in Inventor. It got the gears rolling for my pea-brain to figure out how to make threads... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4880 Added BuckleTube_Female2Buckle.stl to include a version with two buckles. Added BuckleTube_GenderChanger,stl so you can flip orientations of modules. Check out Thaed's print! http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:11434

• Print out all the parts you wish to use.
  • Screw them together in whatever order you feel works best for you.
  • ...
  • Enjoy your MakerBot extendable tube carrier thing with buckles!

comments.text: Works perfectly. I went to TAP Plastics (a local shop that sells and purchased a 12.75" x 12.875" x 0.25" piece of Makrolon AR (http://www.tapplastics.com/product/plastics/cut_to_size_plastic/acrylic_ar_abrasion_resistant_sheets/515) acrylic with 1" radiused corrners. Using the handle as a template, I drilled holes into two pieces of wood. I then clamped the wood to the acrylic to use as a guide and material brace and drilled the holes using a 5/32" drill bit. I attached with 3 x #6-32 x 1" bolts purchased at the local hardware store. Fits perfectly! Pictures coming soon.

author: Spectrom3D

remixed_from.author: pefozzy
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade Accessible Belt Drive Extruder, Rev2

description.text: This is a remix of a solid design by pefozzy. I liked that it supports the hobbed bolt really well with 3 bearings as opposed to two in conventional wade extruders. I also liked the belt driven aspect. One problem I had was sourcing the closed loop belts in the US. My solution was to use MXL belts since they're cheap and easily available. I used a 95MXL belt from McMastercarr for $2.70 a piece: http://www.mcmaster.com/#mxl-series-timing-belts/=uwpq7n. I found on my lab robot/3D printer conversion project I needed a bowden setup so I redesigned this as a bowden extruder with bracket for attaching to any frame. I also made the design more suited for 1.75mm filament since the original one didn't compress the filament enough. I used an aluminum GT2 pulley for the motor, but I've added a printable 20 tooth MXL pulley.

Parts list: Non-Printed parts
2 x 40 mm M4 Hex screws
2 x 5/16 (8mm) x 1.5" (38 mm) springs
1 x Standard 8mm hobbed bolt
1x 8 mm locknut
1 x 95MXL Belt
1 x 20 tooth GT2 Pulley
4 x 608 bearings
1 x 2mm x 1/8" Pneumatic fitting for bowden tube
M8 washers for spacing pulley

A model of a Stanford bunny floating inside an egg shaped cage. The model is designed to test MattS's new printing method using dissolvable support material, HIPS.

The method uses a dual extruder to print the main model in ABS while printing support material in the new material HIPS, which can be dissolved in Limonene, an orange based solvent. The resulting egg cage is pretty delicate as you can see it broke in several places. Size up the model by about 50% will make it sturdier and closer in size to a normal egg. Check out Matt's post here:
http://www.3dppvd.org/wp/2013/02/soluble-support-material/

I made a bumper for an arduino single relay module in order to protect the pins from possible shortcuts, something very dangerous working with AC. description.text:
Yes I know another spool holder for the Printrbot Simple metal, but wait I have reasons. I found with a few spools of filament I have bought recently were too wide to fit on the holder properly so knocked this one up.  
As with others of this design be careful if your print is tall as the spool tends to get caught by the stepper motor as the z axis rises. I might make another change later to combat that problem.  
This is a modification of the previous spool holder I had but can't seem to find where I got it on thingiverse, I will link it if I find it.

Used Slic3r with the standard settings file from Printrbot and at 0.2mm layer thickness.  
Didn't need support.

description.text:
EMT conduit already telescopes, but it is a sloppy fit. These pieces "straighten" up the telescoping ability of EMT conduit. Stop tubes can also be used with Locking Tops. Note: These pieces are meant to be glued onto the EMT. Slip Tube pieces are for the end of the larger tube.
Stop Tube pieces are for the end of the smaller tube Use both together to keep a smaller EMT conduit piece concentric inside a larger piece. More sizes coming soon!
After cutting your EMT to size, make sure to debur the inside and outside of the conduit.

comments.text: These look interesting and may be just the thing for supporting a slave flash / strobe lighting in my photo hobby. Would you mind advising on the type of glue to use? Also what sizes of EMT are these ready to fit straight of the build plate?
comments.author: Gmorris

comments.text:
I actually haven't tried putting them in production yet, so I don't know for sure what type of glue works best. I would assume you will need at least a two part epoxy or construction glue because of the galvanized finish on the EMT. I assume you will have to rough up the EMT as well (sandpaper or file) to expose the metal first.
(I named them glue edition because I do plan to release a version that uses a mechanical tab to lock in place in the future.)
comments.author: Gmorris

description.text: This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

comments.text:
Hey, I was looking through the pdf for these guys with my friend who wants to play them, and was a bit puzzled about the kicker ability shown on the tunneler pod and the clan battlemech, specifically the mech; the mech has a kicker of 6 and a defence of 0 for ballistics and melee, so does this mean the mech is invulnerable to such attacks? The way I understand it is that the mech has 1 defence die of a 6 always, which would counteract any assault made on it, unless attacking with 2 dice would overflow the kicker and damage the mech? This has been a bit puzzling so I decided to ask to get a definite answer.
Thanks for the help!
comments.author: BlueHazmat

comments.text: No worries, that's a great question! Yeah, a kicker counts as an extra die roll that is always that value. So, you were right, you'd have to have at least two OFF dice (or an OFF die and an OFF kicker of your own) to match the 6 and have something left over to take him out. Any time you have questions, hit me up, and so you know, we have a new edition coming out soon that streamlines a lot of subsystems and adds some new ones.
comments.author: BlueHazmat

comments.text:
Cool, thanks a lot!
Now you've made me exited about the new edition.
:P

title: Double Pivot Parametric Filament Guide for P3Steel or Prusa i3 6mm frame

description.text:
This is a redesign of the Filament Guide for the Prusa Mendel by tosjduenfs (thing #34133). I liked the idea of an oscillating arm holding the filament guide but it wouldn't have worked as such with my 3D printer setup: the top of my P3Steel is already way too crowded with a filament spool holder, the bundle of cables for the extruder, and an LCD controller mount. I needed a more flexible solution.  
I designed this double-pivot filament guide so that it tracks the X-carriage motion without getting in the way of other moving or static parts on top of the P3Steel or Prusa i3 6mm frame. It looks good, is small and lightweight, requires little material to print and works well on my P3Steel. I am also using the same design for my Prusa i3 Twelvepro.   
And since every Filament Spool Holder has different dimensions, I made this filament guide parametric: adjust the two arm lengths to suit your particular setup.  
Also you can adjust the frame thickness for a P3Steel (3mm frame thickness) or a Prusa i3 (6mm frame thickness).  
Update 08/12/2014: the frame thickness tolerance is now a separate parameter and can be adjusted to your particular frame (default is 0.1mm).  
OpenSCAD sources are included so the design can be further remixed / optimized.

Easy printing. Here printed in blue PLA with 40% infill with no retraction. Assembly requires 2 x M4 bolts, washers and nyloc nuts, and one small nylon tie. Slide it on the top of your P3Steel or Prusa i3 with 6mm frame then adjust its position. The small nylon tie should be tightened as shown (or you could use a sponge, run the PLA filament through its center and tighten the nylon tie around it, in my case this was unnecessary). Adjusting the parameters in Customizer Arm lengths: I am using 30mm for the short arm and 52mm for the long arm and this configuration works fine on the P3Steel. Adjust these values as required by your particular 3D printer / filament spool holder setup. Frame thickness tolerance: this very much depends on your frame, my advice is to measure its thickness with a caliper and adjust the tolerance so that the pivot part slides on the frame but does not move laterally.

title: Variable Density Insole

description.text:
One of the avenues I am investigating is the problem of foot ulceration, common in diabetes sufferers. This can lead to a serious chain of events leading to over 6000 related amputations a year in the UK. It is estimated that about 80% of these are preventable. Treatment costs to the NHS in the UK are in excess of £650m/annum. It is hoped that a low cost custom insole that is sympathetic to the patients requirements could help dramatically in this scenario. I see 3D printing taking the initiative and leading the solutions once again. This is my latest insole creation. A variable density infill print from a foot scan in Filaflex. Please see more on my blog here (specifically part 3) :
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk/blog/my-adventures-with-3d-printed-insoles-part-1-4
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk/blog/my-adventures-with-3d-printed-insoles-part-2-4
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk/blog/my-adventures-with-3d-printed-insoles-part-3-4
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk/blog/my-adventures-with-3d-printed-insoles-part-4-4 Video : http://youtu.be/ix5e9w-F4HQ

description.header: EDIT 10/06/2016 : This work is superseded by my software over at http://www.gensole.com
description.text:
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

I used Gimp to separate out the regions. Then Inkscape to make the vector files. I then exported .dxf files from Inkscape, which can then be imported in to a cad program. Once the curves have been turned into stls, then its over to Slic3r and using it's modifier mesh option, different infill densities can be applied to different regions.? Please see more on my blog here (specifically part 3) :
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk/blog/my-adventures-with-3d-printed-insoles-part-1-4

comments.text:
Hi Gyrobot,
My name is Dario. I am a high school student and I'm working on a similar project for school.
I like to call my project Precision Insole Printing (PIP) because I think it is the future in the medical world for the production of insoles for people with rheumatic feet and diabetes for example.
My idea is as follows, the traditional way of producing the insoles for patients is now milling or making the sole handmade. Both of these ways result in pollution by micro-dust. I think that if we use 3D printing, instead of eliminating the material laying it down, we can solve the pollution problem and have a faster and preciser production method.
comments.author: PrecisionInsolePrinting

comments.text:
Hi Dario,
Thank you for your kind words. I have now further advanced this design and printing technique. Combining variable density infills and form fitting the upper surface to a foot scan reduced peak plantar pressure by 33% on initial trials, ideal for diabetic patients

author: TrevM

description.text: ACCROCHE

UPDATE: I am marking this one up as a flawed design and will upload a corrected version.  The end that has openings for the battery wires is far too weak.  As a beginner in quads I am finding the groud jumps up and hits these things all the time (It couldn't be my flying at fault :) ).  At any rate, these need to be more substantial to take a beating.  Leaving it up in case anyone takes a shot at fixing it before I do.  
This is a battery tray designed to house a Venom 20C 3200mAh battery using the standard holes on the bottom of the x525 fiberglass center platform.  I made this to keep the battery from sliding in the battery strap and shifting the center of gravity of the quadcopter.  Sorry about the part rotation, will fix this and re-upload.  Use, modify, and comment as you wish.  Feedback is always welcome.  
Update: Uploaded a new STL to correct the part rotation.  Both parts are in one file.  Let me know if you want them split up.
Just trying to design something better than the "V" shaped skids that are hard to keep in place and stick in the grass when flying low

description.text: pdragy's Snowflake Icosahedron Ornament set includes a twenty-snowflake set (nineteen sides and one top) fitted to a Makerbot Replicator 2, but that's too big to fit my Flashforge Creator. So I ran the single snowflake through SketchUp and the Cleanup³ plugin, then made STLs that have eight, and twelve, snowflakes. This will make it easy to produce enough to make a few ornaments even for a printer not quite as big as the Makerbot Rep2. You'll still print the tops separately, though.
See the original design for the top piece and instructions.
